sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a vaporization reaction
message_1: Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the vaporization of 25.0 g of water at 100°C, given that the molar enthalpy of vaporization of water is 40.7 kJ/mol. (The molar mass of water is 18.015 g/mol.)
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the vaporization of 25.0 g of water, we first need to determine the number of moles of water present. We can do this using the molar mass of water:

moles of water = (mass of water) / (molar mass of water)
moles of water = (25.0 g) / (18.015 g/mol)
moles of water ≈ 1.387 moles

Now that we have the number of moles of water, we can use the molar enthalpy of vaporization to calculate the standard enthalpy change:

ΔH = (moles of water) × (molar enthalpy of vaporization)
ΔH = (1.387 moles) × (40.7 kJ/mol)
ΔH ≈ 56.4 kJ

Therefore, the standard enthalpy change for the vaporization of 25.0 g of water at 100°C is approximately 56.4 kJ.
